description: From Middle English cyvyl, civil, borrowed from Old French civil, from Latin cīvīlis (“relating to a citizen”), from cīvis (“citizen”). Cognate with Old English hīwen (“household”), hīrǣden (“family”). More at hind; hird. Doublet of civic.

adjectives.description: civil (comparative more civil, superlative most civil)

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Having to do with people and government office as opposed to the military or religion.
examples: She went into civil service because she wanted to help the people.

entries.meaning: (comparable) Behaving in a reasonable or polite manner.
examples: It was very civil of him to stop the argument.
Antonyms: anti-civil, impolite, inconsiderate, noncivil, rude

entries.meaning: (archaic) In a peaceful and well-ordered state.
(law) Relating to private relations among citizens, as opposed to criminal matters.
